title: Commemorating the 75th Anniversary of The Mary Louis Academy
fulltext:
LEGISLATIVE  RESOLUTION  commemorating  the 75th Anniversary of The Mary
Louis Academy

WHEREAS, It is the sense of  this  Legislative  Body  to  recognize  and
commend  those  institutions  of  commitment  and high achievement whose
purpose and endeavors prove a dedication to the pursuit of excellence in
the education of the young women of this noble Empire State; and
  WHEREAS, Attendant to such concern, and in full accord with its  long-
standing  traditions,  this  Legislative Body is justly proud to commem-
orate the 75th Anniversary of The Mary Louis Academy, to  be  celebrated
on March 25, 2011; and
  WHEREAS,  Established  in  1936,  The  Mary  Louis  Academy in Jamaica
Estates, New York, is a Catholic college preparatory  school  for  young
women sponsored by the Sisters of St. Joseph of Brentwood, New York; all
graduating  receive  a New York State Regents diploma and well more than
90% receive New York State Regents diplomas with  Advanced  Designation,
the State of New York's highest academic standard; and
  WHEREAS,  In  a  world  increasingly impersonal and technological, The
Mary Louis Academy endeavors to empower  each  student  to  realize  and
value  her  own spiritual, intellectual, physical, emotional, and social
potential; and
  WHEREAS, The Mary Louis Academy guides its  students  toward  academic
excellence,  where knowledge is set in the context of faith, so that its
graduates may develop a life vision characterized by wisdom; and
  WHEREAS, Although Mother Mary Louis passed away on May 22,  1932,  her
dream  of establishing an academy for young women in the Jamaica Estates
area lived on in the hearts and minds of her  congregation  of  sisters;
and
  WHEREAS,  The  first  students at The Mary Louis Academy were 57 young
women who were greeted by a faculty of eight sisters on the first day of
school on September 14, 1936;  classes  were  held  in  the  Mary  Louis
Convent adjoining the school while plans for the permanent building were
formulated; and
  WHEREAS,  The completed school building, housed at the address of 176-
21 Wexford Terrace in Jamaica Estates, New York, took shape over a peri-
od of two years and finally opened its doors on October  16,  1938;  the
stated  purpose  of the Academy was to educate young women to take their
places in society and contribute to the world; in order to achieve  this
purpose, a demanding academic program was introduced; and
  WHEREAS, From the very beginning, a variety of extra-curricular activ-
ities extended the interests of the students; MARIEL, the school newspa-
per, published its first issue in 1936; the Glee Club and Orchestra, the
Drama  Club  Genesians, and the language clubs fostered student talents;
and
  WHEREAS, The Mary Louis Academy's Athletic Association sponsored field
days and many intramural events; the Christmas Pageant, sponsored by the
Sodality, became an annual event; and
  WHEREAS, The reputation for academic  excellence  at  The  Mary  Louis
Academy quickly spread and so many young women had sought to be educated
there;  less  than  20 years after its founding, the school's population
had outgrown the building; in 1956, the new  wing  was  opened  and  the
capacity of the school had doubled; and
  WHEREAS,  Today,  technology plays an ever-expanding role in the peda-
gogical practices at Mary  Louis  Academy;  in  the  mid-1930s,  it  was
considered  a heroic act of faith to establish a school; in the midst of
The Great Depression, when the prevailing spirit was one  of  pessimism,

building  a  school  was a statement of belief in the future, and in the
contributions of Catholic education to that future; and
  WHEREAS,  The  founders  of  Mary  Louis were women of great faith and
vision; they saw the women who graduated from the Mary Louis Academy  as
a force for good in society; and
  WHEREAS,  Ably led by its Principal Sister Kathleen McKinney, The Mary
Louis Academy continues to prosper today and into the future; and
  WHEREAS, Within the  21st  Century,  The  Mary  Louis  Academy  stands
prepared to reach out, in earnest and enthusiastic quest of its mission,
to  promote  the maximum growth of every student, establishing standards
and building skills which will carry its students and  the  citizens  of
its community into the future; now, therefore, be it
  RESOLVED,  That  this  Legislative  Body pause in its deliberations to
commemorate the 75th Anniversary of The Mary Louis Academy;  and  be  it
further
  RESOLVED, That a copy of this Resolution, suitably engrossed, be tran-
smitted to Principal Sister Kathleen McKinney, The Mary Louis Academy.
